revision.text:
<!-- This article is a part of [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft]]. Please see [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Aircraft/page content]] for recommended layout. --> {|{{Infobox Aircraft Begin |name=YO-51 Dragonfly |image=YO-51 Dragonfly takeoff.jpg |caption= }}{{Infobox Aircraft Type |type=Army observation and liaison |manufacturer=[[Ryan Aeronautical]] |designer= |first flight=1940 |introduced= |retired= |status= |primary user= [[United States Army Air Corps]] |more users= |produced= |number built=three |variants with their own articles= }} |} The '''Ryan YO-51 Dragonfly''' was an [[observation aircraft]] designed and built by [[Ryan Aeronautical]] for the [[United States Army Air Corps]] (USAAC). A single-engined [[parasol wing]] [[monoplane]], it was designed for optimum [[STOL]] capability, but although three prototypes proved highly successful in testing, the [[Stinson YO-49]] was judged superior and no production contract was placed.
==Design== The design of the YO-51 Dragonfly was typical for aircraft of its type, being optimised for the observation and liaison role, with emphasis on the ability to operate out of the smallest possible airfields.<ref>Penfield 1941, p.31.</ref> The Dragonfly was a high-wing braced [[parasol wing|parasol]] [[monoplane]] with fixed tailwheel [[landing gear]], a two-seat open cockpit, and full-span [[Leading edge slot|slots]] and [[Fowler flaps]] for [[STOL]] capability.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Foottit|first=H. R.|date=February 1942|title=The Fowler Flap|journal=[[Flying (magazine)|Flying and Popular Aviation]]|publisher=Ziff-Davis Publishing Co.|location=Chicago|volume=30|issue=2|page=71}}</ref> It was powered by a single [[Pratt & Whitney R-985]]-21 Wasp Junior [[radial engine]].<ref name="DD">Donald 1997, p.794.</ref>
At gross weight, the YO-51 could, without flaps, take off after a run of 400 feet, while with full flaps the takeoff run would be only 75 feet, or just four feet more than twice its own length.<ref>Fowler 1948, p.79.</ref> The Dragonfly was capable of maintaining level flight at speeds as low as {{convert|30|mph}},<ref>Rowe 2006, p.22.</ref> and was claimed as being capable of landing in a distance shorter than the length of the aircraft itself.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Wilson|first=Gill Robb|date=July 1954|title=Genealogy of American Aircraft|journal=[[Flying (magazine)|Flying]]|publisher=Ziff-Davis Publishing Co.|location=Chicago|volume=55|issue=1|page=23}}</ref>
==Operational history== Nicknamed the "flying motorcycle",<ref>{{cite news|title=U. S. Army's "Flying Motorcycle"|date=May 25, 1941|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|page=C1|location=Boston, MA}}</ref> three YO-51 aircraft were acquired by the United States Army Air Corps to take part in a [[fly-off]] evaluation against the [[Stinson YO-49]] and [[Bellanca YO-50]] to supply a new observation and liaison aircraft for use by the USAAC.<ref>Pattillo 2001, p.137.</ref> The YO-51 was the heaviest of the three aircraft evaluated.<ref>Adcock 2005, p.5.</ref>
Although the Dragonfly was considered satisfactory during its flight testing,<ref>{{cite news|title=The Dragonfly---Army's Newest Observation Plane|date=February 23, 1940|work=[[The Milwaukee Sentinel]]|page=2|location=Milwaukee, WI}}</ref> conducted at [[Wright Field]] in Ohio,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F40614F73955177A93C5A8178AD95F448485F9|title=Army Tests New B-17C|date=November 17, 1940|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2012-08-11|location=New York}}</ref> the Stinson machine won the production contract, and no further YO-51s were built.<ref>Merriam 2002, p.26.</ref>
